sourceDesc.p: This is the feature-file for PFV inflection: 3pl.m/c in III w/y verbs.

revisionDesc.change: For EGY-___ there are no values found
updating references to Zotero IDs via update-bibl-refs.xsl

wib:featureValueObservation.note: Some elderly speakers (+70) show -um mainly, but there is also variation with -yu.
No examples are provided but pattern CiCu is described for both CiCi (nisi) verbs and CaCa verbs (ʕaṭa).
-yu is used in fəʕi type verbs, -u is used in faʕa type verbs.
-u is used in faʕa type verbs, -yu is used in fəʕi type verbs.
In this dialect, all the defective IIIw verbs have become IIIy verbs and therefore take the -yu suffix.
Both -a type (laʔa) and -i type (miši) verbs take -yu.
Both -a type verbs (ʕaṭa) and -i / ə verbs (nisi) take -yu.
For CiCi type verbs.
For CaCa type verbs.
All verbs are CiCa verbs.
According to the source there are 2 different edings for the qatala inflection (-am and -ow), however Cantineau does not indicate under which conditions they are used
According to the source there are 2 different edings for the qatala inflection (-am and -ow), however Cantineau does not indicate under which conditions they are used

Talay (1999) differentiates between an a-type and an ə-type. This example is an a-type verb. The verb "to forget" can be conjugated in both ways: nasaw and nəsyu.
Talay (1999) differentiates between an a-type and an ə-type. This example is an ə-type verb. The verb "to forget" can be conjugated in both ways: nasaw and nəsyu.
Behnstedt (1997) differentiates between an a-type and an i-type. This example is an a-type verb.
Behnstedt (1997) differentiates between an a-type and an i-type. This example is an i-type verb.
Behnstedt (1994) divides defective verbs into three different types: (1) pure a-type, (2) pure i-type and (3) a mixed type. "laka" is an example for a pure a-type.
Behnstedt (1994) divides defective verbs into three different types: (1) pure a-type, (2) pure i-type and (3) a mixed type. " The example is a pure i-type.

cit.quote: they became free, they are free

wib:featureValueObservation.note: According to Wittrich (2001) the suffix turns into -aw when verbs end with the long vowel ā: banā + -u becomes banaw
Talay (2009) divides two types of defective verbs: (1) Verba tertiae w: CaCa (like ʕaṭa) and (2) Verba tertiae y: CaCa (like baqa)
Talay (2009) divides two types of defective verbs: (1) Verba tertiae w: CaCa (like ʕaṭa) and (2) Verba tertiae y: CaCa (like baqa)
Löhr (1905) divides two different types of defective verbs; Type 1: fiʕil and type 2: faʕal
Löhr (1905) divides two different types of defective nouns; Type 1: fiʕil and type 2: faʕal
Behnstedt (1997) differentiates between an a-type and an i-type. This example is an a-type verb.
Behnstedt (1997) differentiates between an a-type and an i-type. This example is an i-type verb.
Behnstedt (1997) differentiates between an a-type and an i-type. However, the Naem conjugate both in the same way.
Behnstedt (1997) differentiates between an a-type and an i-type. This example is an a-type verb.
Behnstedt (1997) differentiates between an a-type and an i-type. This example is an i-type verb.
Behnstedt (1997) differentiates between an a-type and an i-type. However, in Raqqa both types are conjugated in the same way.
If a defective verbs ends with an -i (nisi), the vowel is retained as y.
If a defective verbs ends with an -a (ʔara), the vowel gets replaced by the verbal suffix -u.

Leitner (2022) notes that the second vowel "a" of a verb with a final week root combines with the final root consonant and therefore the stem ends in "i" or "a". Verbs with a final root consonant ʔ have the same structure and always end with "a".
Deduced from examples
Maltese orthography: mxew
Panetta (1943) also attests -ō alongside -ow, but no example is provided
Panetta (1943) also attests -ō alongside -ow, but no example is provided
Johnstone (1967:50) states that this ending is typical of all eastern Arabian dialects, and is not specific for Bahrain. There is also no distinction between the ʕArab and the Baḥārna communities
Johnstone (1967:50) states that this ending is typical of all eastern Arabian dialects, and is not specific for Bahrain. There is also no distinction between the ʕArab and the Baḥārna communities
A particularity of the Baḥārna dialect is that, in the s-stem of verbs the /a/-type, the radical /y/ shows up in the 3rd person forms (Holes 2016:210)
Johnstone (1967:50) states that this ending is typical of all eastern Arabian dialects, and is not specific for Kuwait
Deduced from examples

Johnstone (1967:50) states that this ending is typical of all eastern Arabian dialects and is not specific for Qatar. Johnstone (1967:113) states that for Qatar there is a tendency for forms of the pattern fiʕil to occur, e.g. miši, but he does not give an example for the 3.P.Pl.M.
This verb follows the pattern C1aC2a (Johnstone 1988:90)
This verb follows the pattern C1aC2i, but before vocalic endings the stem is C1aC2y- (Johnstone 1988:91)
This verb follows the pattern C1VC2a (Johnstone 1988:91)
This verb follows the pattern C1iC2i, but before vocalic endings the stem is C1aC2y- (Johnstone 1988:91-92)

In some cases, Koiné-forms like riḍyu "she agreed" or even hypercorrections like "garyu" instead of "gaṛaw" can occur.
